title: Overly complicated folding 25mm model paint rack
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A folding rack to hold 30 25mm bottles of miniature paint.

Needs 16 x 3/8 long 6-32 screws to attach rails to rack pieces, and 4 x 3/4 long 6-32 screws to attach legs. Leave all screws a little loose so that the pivots move freely.

Due to the way my files get exported the STLs are rather randomly oriented, when laid down, they are all printable without supports.

The shape of the slot on the legs is useful for locking them in the out position, they move about halfway out when tilting the unit, but need to be moved manually the rest of the way.

description.text:
A small, 180 class quadcopter frame made of Electrical-grade fiberglass. This frame is lighter than any other I have flown and handles the best out of all of them. Most importantly, it can handle crashes extremely well, even better with carbon fiber.

Frame folds for traveling be removing 2+ of the center bolts on the base plates.

Designed for 5 inch propellers and 16-19mm motor bolt spacing. Includes optional spacers to be printed and placed under 2 motors to ensure propeller clearance.

All parts were cut on 4'X8' Shopbot with a 1/8" carbide bit.
1 in/s feedrate with 3 passes.
3d-printed standoffs and motor spacers printed on Flashforge Creator Pro with ABS plastic

Frame was only 77 grams on its own.

Pictured above:
Motors- Multistar Elite 2204-2300kV
ESC- Afro 12A esc
Control Board- Naze32 Acro
PDB- Hovership Micro (replacing soon)
Battery- Zippy 1800mAh 25c (normally Lumenier 1500mAh 45c)
Weight w/o Battery- 293 grams

The fiberglass was 1/8" thick bought from McMaster-Carr and was a cheap alternative to Carbon fiber. Links below:

Fiberglass- https://www.mcmaster.com/#standard-fiberglass-sheets/=14so9lf

Carbon Fiber- https://www.mcmaster.com/#standard-carbon-fiber-sheets/=14soc4f

Required parts (for frame):

Fiberglass or Carbon Fiber
4x Arms
2x Base plate
1x top plate
M3 bolts for motors
4x 12mm M3 bolts (for inner base plate bolts)
4x 8mm M3 bolts (for top plate mount)
4x 25+mm M3 bolts (for stacking CB and PDB)
4x Printed Standoffs (or your choice of standoffs)
Assortment of provided M3 spacers

P.S. I know my build is messy. I have plans on fixing it soon.

title: Samsung S6 dash mount for Citi Golf MKI
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Dash mount in front of the steering wheel for a Samsung Galaxy S6 that is fitted with a Body Glove. The phone screen is visible above the steering wheel and the phone itself obscures a minimum amount of dashboard.

Fits post-2004 VW Golf 1. The Golf 1 continued manufacture in South Africa and in 2004 was updated using the dashboard from a Škoda Fabia so I guess the mount would fit that car too.

......yes, my car is dusty inside (a flash shows every little speck).....

I'm thinking of making a version with a horn to amplify the speaker.

I stuck mine down with "No More Nails" double sided tape. It may be difficult to see from the photos, but there is actually a flat lip on the steering column.

author: springclip

description.text:
I liked the ideas from henryarnold's airtight filament container, but the spool holder he designed didn't work for me. Very difficult to put together and didn't fit my spools right. I modified the side pieces, and redid the rest of the design.

I had a pile of cheap 608 bearings laying around, so I decided to make a holder that would fit my spools. This one should fit a good width range.

It does use 8x 608 bearings, so I doubt many will use this design, but it works great for me.

The "bars" that hold the bearings are split down the middle and can be printed without any supports. The bearings will actually hold them together or a little glue works as well. Just snap it all together and a bit of glue at the ends and you are done. There is a very small lip on the top part of the side (to keep the edges of the bearing from going flush against it and rubbing as well as on the bar spacers, so make sure you put the surface side of the side piece on the inside.

I printed this on a small printer (120mm x 120mm bed). The side pieces will fit if turned 45 degrees. I printed all 4 of the bar pieces at once with no issues.

Designed in Tinkercad

Printer:

Monoprice MP Select Mini

description.text:
I combined the motor mounts from the three different frames for this thing (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1715901) into one object. Print this using the same settings that you intend to print the frame. Then test fit your motor to decide which frame works best.

0.00 = MiniWhoop_Frame_v20.stl
0.25 = MiniWhoop_Frame_0.25margin.stl
0.40 = MiniWhoop_Frame_0.4margin.stl

Avoids doing a long print to find out it doesn't fit your motors.

This case is perfect for using your iPhone when it's hailing, or when it's too sunny to see your screen properly, or when onlookers are trying to peek at your screen. 
It also gives a classic victorian styling to your modern age device!

Print the shutters and the case. Insert your phone into the case, and then slide the shutters into place. Some light sanding may be required to get everything working smoothly.
The top right handle on each shutter is designed so that you can use a thread to connect all of the shutters together.
Both stls have been included. If you want to play with the openscad file, then grab the file "iphone4 model.scad" as it relies on it.
I took pains to make this a printible piece, as I was disappointed by the sheer number of EvD entries that are unprintible, and wouldn't even work if they could be printed.
This product is a parody, and is intended for the Engineer vs designer absurd iPhone contest. Save your breath if you want to tell me it is absurd. Or better yet, tell the fine folks over at EvD!

title: Remix of Prusa i3v E3d Titan Mount

description.text:
I wanted to be able to adjust some key dimensions on this, so I used the bracket design from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1540768 & carriage design from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1235817 to make an openscad file that was adjustable. I had a problem with getting the eccentric wheel tight after printing from a printer that was a little out of calibration the 1st time I printed this part, so I added the optional additional wheel tensioner cut as used on this part: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1825040 . The cooling fan design as shown in the 2nd image is from here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1571526 . There is not Z Probe with this design, but I might add one later.

The titan extruder blank I used was: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1514324 & the e3d Lite6 hotend model I used was: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1718350

I included 2 stl files with & without the additional wheel tensioning option.(Prusa_I3v_Titan_Mount_WithWheelTensionCutout_Rev19.stl, Prusa_I3v_Titan_Mount_Rev19.stl) as well as the openscad source file. The other STL files are used for reference in the assembly display in the openscad file

I also used a 5mm diameter hole for motor mounts as was used with http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1540768 design. Change the variable Mot_Hole_OD = 3.6 if you want a tighter tolerance for these holes. You can also change the wheel spacing & belt tensioning spacing if you want. The design I remixed has 49.4mm for the belt tensioning.

The M3 locknut for the right side of the belt clamp is pretty close to hitting the titan extruder & if I printed this again, I would probably shift the extruder up another 1mm by changing Bracket_Y_Offset = 2; and change Line 335 to:
rotate([0,33.3,0])

I have not finished hooking up the wiring, but it fits on the V-Slot nicely & I have more X-carriage width & will have to move the X limit switch in a little.

title: 4" dia Rubens Tube 100mm speaker driver adaptor

description.text:
Make flames react and "dance" to music with a Ruben's tube!
This part allows you to mount a 100mm audio speaker driver to the end of a 4" metal vent pipe for use with a Rubens tube.
The rubens tube creates a pressure wave within a tube full of propane or LP gas (modulated from any recorded audio source - like music) which causes flames to dance and react to music playing through the speaker.
For more info check out this WikiPedia article: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rubens%27_tube

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 4

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Infill:

50

Notes:

Support is built in to the model, so should not be necessary.
Printing in ABS or temperature-tolerant material is advisable since the metal tube may heat up during use.

Assembly

Wrap a piece of mylar balloon or very thin foil to the outside of the tube before installing this adaptor, to keep the gas from leaking through your speaker cone- also providing a membrane for increased pressure.
I recommend a temperature-tolerant silicone or caulking to adhere the adaptor to the tube.
I used brass heat-insert nuts (M3) and socket-cap screws to attach the speaker to the mount. I also used the high-temp silicone to around the outside circumference of the speaker to create a better seal.
I also created several variations of a custom cap for the other end of the tube that fits a valve I stole from my BBQ grill. I'll upload that soon and link it here.
Designed from scratch in OpenSCAD

These are simple gauges for determining approximately how much filament is needed for a given object. An object of a given cubic size would require the stated length of filament. Assuming I did my math right, we have: 1/8\" filament, 1mm shell, 30% infill
.5\" cube = .5ft
1\" cube = 3ft
2\" cube = 20.6ft
3\" cube = 64.8ft and 3mm filament, 1mm shell, 30% infill
12.5mm cube = .16m
25mm cube = 1m
50mm cube = 6.73m
75mm cube = 21.16m Since ABS has a density of about 0.037 lbs/cubic inch, 5lbs works out to about 917 linear feet of 1/8\" filament (seems like a lot to me - can someone with a printer confirm?). So you can use this to keep track of how much you\'ve used. You could also use a cheap scale, but you can\'t print one...yet. Edited to add: Not sure why the renders are showing mirrored text. My original files are fine, but I've uploaded mirrored files just in case. Edited to add: Per Bophoto's suggestion, I've recalculated these for a 1mm solid shell and 30% filled interior volume and replaced the files.

1) Print (should be ok, but I don't yet have a printer, so I haven't tested it)
2) Use
3) Gloat if necessary

c) Skeinforge tells you exactly how much filament is use

more information about schematics and how (and why) to setup your printer with a mosfet you can find in the WIKI pages https://3dprint.wiki/reprap/electronics/heatbed_mosfet

The topbit screws onto your frame as usual the bottom bit for the mosfet has on its back room to insert some M3 nuts for the screws to fasten into so no holes drilling in your acryllic frame required just add the wiring and fire safety is 90% better.

I used an easy way to wire this using the stock 12 volts wire. Without cutting it , just removing about 1 cm of the insulation (to connect the mosfet), ran it from psu to mosfet to controlboard.

EDIT : WITH THE INTRODUCTION OF THE NEWER TYPE CONNECTORS ON THE CONTROLBOARD THE POLARITY OF THE 12 VOLT IN CONNECTOR HAS BEEN REVERSED, ALWAYS FOLLOW THE MARKINGS ON THE BOARD FOR (red) + AND (black/*red) - FOR WIRING.

comments.author: PlanC

comments.text:
the control in line (signal line) that is the little white connector needs a simple little bit of wire that connects to the controlboard where the hotbed WAS connected, there is just a little signal going through there with a lot higher resistance and virtually no current anymore. the bed with its low resistance is no longer connected to it.
The 12 volts connection: Always follow the connections marked on the boards for + and -. There are different versions of controllboards, where the INPUT for 12 volts have been reversed with the introduction of the newer type connectors.+ goes on + always, and - on to the -

comments.author: 67Andy

comments.text: I thought their is supposed to be a separate wire supplying power to the board and to the module, but youre method seems more elegant . this method saves me a lot of wire running all the way back to the ps, have u had any issues this way???  thanks , imprinting this thing now.
comments.author: Tmask32

comments.text: Hi, i've had this methode of wiring for around 6 weeks now and no problem. The wire itself is thick enough to carry the total current of the printer. the melting problems always happens where there is a connection (bad connection in this case with the green connectors) with a transitional resistence, and the heat developement in the bit where the resistence is. Make sure you don't cut the wire (where it is connected to the mosfet), just carefully make a cut around the plastic insulation and remove about 1 cm, leave the coppercore intact, loop the wire from psu to mosfet to controlboard. The bulk of the current will be diverted away from the controlboard and the mosfet will do what its there for.
comments.author: Tmask32

comments.text: most people probably want to use separate 12volt wires for the mosfet and controlboard. I did not have a suitable piece of wire lying around and did not want to have to go to a shop, that's why i used the lazy way ;-) since the stockwire is thick enough to carry all the current

Assembling

1) Check with a needle, that all holes are open.
2) Use a small LED, the plus - pole belongs in the tilted hole.
3) Use a 47 Ohm resistor, cut one end a little bit shorter (Picture); Put this end in the hole, where the plus - pole from the LED gets out. Fix the resistor and the other end of the wire in the notch with a little bit of glue.
4) Use a CR2032 Batterie or similar. The "+" is at the bottom.
5) Close the clap.
Ready!

description.text:
This object has been drawn and printed by students aged 14-15 of Kirkby Stephen Grammar School.
The activity has been carried out within the Erasmus+ Project PRINT STEM www.printstemprojects.eu and co-funded by the Italian National Agency INDIRE.

title: Custom Mendel90 X Ends with Zip Tie holes

description.text:
These are the x ends for a Mendel90 that I changed a bit.

  • Removed part of the walls that hold in the lm8uu bearings to allow them to fit in without having to heat the part with a blow dryer.

  • Added zip tie holders.

  • Added a bit more room for the bearing so its not such a tight fit.

  • On the motor end, changed the motor holes to be just tiny divots. I was having a hard time getting that 45 degree wall to print cleanly at high speed, so instead I just drill out the holes using the divots as center marks.

  • On the motor end, removed the mounts for ribbon cables because I just don't use them. Just plain old wires for me.

print_settings.Notes:: This Oxygen Tank Wrench goes under lots of torque pressure from the steel valve when being turned. I suggest making the infill 50% or more. I did 25% and it works good, but you can tell that after about 25 or 50 uses that the plastic is getting indented. So to get a reliable Oxygen Tank Wrench I suggest making it more solid in case of emergencies.

description.text: I needed an oxygen tank wrench that was convenient enough to clip to my wheelchair for easy access for quick changes of oxygen tanks when needed. I was in need of a new wrench and I used to carry a regular adjustable wrench you get from any hardware store but that was too much of a hassle and would always smack the metal on my wheelchair and make a loud clanking sound when I was driving around. This is an Oxygen Tank Wrench that I designed will fit an oxygen tank used for medical reasons. It fits the steel tank valves on top of each tank that must be turned to open and allow oxygen to flow to the recipient. This can also be used for oxygen tanks or other similar tanks for glass blowing, or other uses not just for medical reasons. It has a designated hoop on one end for a key chain ring to hang off of whatever you want. I attached it to a retractable ID key chain so I always know where it is.

Printer:

Flashforge Dreamer

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

50%

Notes:

This Oxygen Tank Wrench goes under lots of torque pressure from the steel valve when being turned. I suggest making the infill 50% or more. I did 25% and it works good, but you can tell that after about 25 or 50 uses that the plastic is getting indented. So to get a reliable Oxygen Tank Wrench I suggest making it more solid in case of emergencies.

Steps Taken To Design

I designed this in Tinkercad. Then I brought it into 123D Design to help refine the straight edges and make them a little round for an easy slip onto the valves.

description.text:
This is a remix of the fan duct holder by Thorped - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1246425

It has M4 threading to make it easier to screw the fan to the hold.

You'll need two M4x20mm screws, they will fit perfectly with a 50x50x15mm blower fan.

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3 or 0.2 till Z8.2, 0.1 above Z8.2

Infill:

30%

Notes:

I used Simplify3D to slice this.

I made two processes, the first one had a layer height of 0.2, the second one had a layer height of 0.1. You should print with resolution 0.2 till Z 8.2, then with 0.1 resolution.

At Z 8.2 the M4 thread begins, so using 0.1 resolution will make it more precise.

If you are using another slicer without this flexibility I'd suggest you print the entire part at 0.1.

Rhino project

I created this modular electric skateboard / longboard enclosure to house my electronics under my longboard. You can print in any material you like but keep in mind that the material you choose should have a high thermal rating as electronics can get hot and potentially melt some filament types. I've had success with PolyPLA and Alloy910 but you may want to choose something with even greater thermal properties. Either way, this is a rigid enclosure as it is 3 mm thick which makes it nice and strong. I used 50 percent infill which seems plenty strong but you may want to try a higher infill rate. Lastly i've uploaded two pieces, basically an end piece and middle piece, you can print as many middle pieces as you like to get the length you need or just print two end pieces if that is all you require. Thanks for you looking at my enclosure and ride safe !

End piece Dimensions
External Dimensions

22 chamfers
10 mm Lips on 3 sides

174 x 177
3 mm thick

Line drawing in Rhino

now the contest is over here is all the solid works files as promised. Enjoy, i hope someone will find this useful - iv printed a full set out since uploading and i have to say, even i had fun with it! PollyBlox is a fun polygon learning tool for children capable of allowing children to make all regular pollygons from Triangles to Dodecagons, Circles, 5 pointed Stars and more!
This set also allows Children to build 3d models from the pieces by inserting a "connector peg" into the center hole to allow two "blocks" to join together in the vertical axis.
The Quadrilateral is 25mm x 25mm in size (aprox 1") this makes it great for learning area ^2 or ^3 too! PollyBlox is designed to allow children to have a hands on and fun learning experience. I know this was the way i learned and still do. Books and diagrams just never got it across in a way that was most effective for me as a child so with this in mind PollyBlox was born. i've added in a few screenshots for you guys as an example of a few potential assemblies.

I've only had a chance to test print a few bits to test the fit and it seems good for me. - ill take feedback and make any improvements needed (full source files will be available soon)  
To print, simply make a print plate with all the "Blox" you require, make sure to add enough connectors to connect it all up  :)  
To assemble simply take a "Blox" and a connector, slide the connector into one of the slots or a hole. take another "Blox" and simply slide it in on the other side or end of the connector.

comments.text: Wow!  I love all of your PollyBlox.  I want to play and make shapes.  I am a 54-year old kid.  :-)

Corners for mounting a Prusa Mendel on top of a milk crate.

Print two lefts, two rights, and four supports.  Zip tie the corners to the crate and mound the supports to your machine.  The machine should now sit well on top of a milk crate.  I have mine tied on for improved stability and ease of transportation.
I have included two types of supports.  One is intended to be attached to your machine by the bottom rod that goes through the foot.  The other is simply a spacer that fits around the foot and between my power mount and the corner.  
I made some bottom vertexes with a protrusion that eliminates the need for the spacers.

title: Wanhao Duplicator i3 E3D Titan Extruder mount

description.text:
This Extruder/hotend assembly is made to fit the Wanhao Duplicator i3 and other named versions of this printer.

It features an easily serviceable design and has an effective part cooling fan with a non obtrusive view to your prints.
The E3D Titan Extruder is a light weight geared extruder, combined with the E3D v6 hotend it performs superbly with almost every filament out there. I´m using the lightweight Bipolar Nema 17 stepping motor part number 17HS10-0704S. It´s a perfect match for this geared extruder, even smaller pancake steppers can also be used
Animation: https://youtu.be/lNlH0MjzrrM

Features:

  • Adjustable belt tensioning
  • Easy access to filament tension screw.
  • Easy to exchange filament
  • Fully supported filament path for flexible materials
  • Effective part cooling fan
  • Easy servicing and access to the extruder
  • BLTouch mount positioning for auto bed leveling
  • Fan grill with mount points for the X-axis end stop switch and drag chain.
  • Wire mounting point

comments.text: Any reason you chose to have the blower only in one direction rather than an omni or multi direction cooler like the dii cooler or one of its variants?
comments.author: kingofkings

comments.text: dii cooler (old type) has low visibility of parts being printed, and can fill up with plastic if a print fails. Can be a mess to clean up, and take out a few parts in your hot end, in extremes could be dangerous. A blower will probably have sufficient cooling at about 60% speed. this design is quite effective, cools and blows heat away from the part and heat radiating from bed. If I needed more cooling I would go for a cobra style.

title: Modern Robotics Electronics Encasing for First Tech Challenge

description.text:
Hello everyone! This a design that we think a lot of teams will find helpful. We've included STEP files so you can customize to your liking. Please show us pictures and what we can fix! Thank you and good luck this season!

Assembly Video: https://youtu.be/Fn5wr8I2HYc
Assembly Video: https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=aG6mBrcCaaE

These 3D prints allow for maximum compactness when mounting electronics on your robot. When maintenance is required, instead of having to unscrew 8 different lock nuts and rearrange stuff (especially in time crunch), it's as easy as sliding and interlocking like puzzles!

Feel free to create more attachments and adjustments! We would appreciate however that you add the to the end of the title: "EE V1" so we can sustain compatibility. Thanks!

Print at most 100 microns with no support and in the orientation the file is in.

Cataclysm Robotics is part of Mount Si Robotics Club.

UPDATE 11/28/2016
Hello again! Hope everyone's seasons are going great! All parts are good! Thanks for everyone's patience! We are working on getting some extra attachments for a Phone and the Sensor Module and will post when ready!

UPDATE 11/7/2016
Hey everybody! We had some clogging trouble with our printer last week but we've fixed that now, so Part 4 & Part 5 should be deemed "Good" at the end of this week. Thanks for all you comments and feedback!

UPDATE 10/29/2016
Tolerances for Part 1 & Part 2, Power Controller, Servo & Motor Controller are good! (This means they have been printed and all fit at 100 micron layer thickness)

Resolution:

100 Microns (0.1 mm)

Infill:

10+%

description.text:
Here's my plans for a battery powered data-logger based on a pyboard and a DHT11 sensor. The battery usage (3 x AA Ni-MH) is low enough that the logger can be left somewhere remote for at least a month before the batteries need recharging.

The box has been frankensteined from at least four things on thingiverse. The outer box is a resized version of this RAMPS box. The battery pack is from this flexing battery holder with the bottom cut off it. The pyboard tray is based on this thing with a coin cell holder tacked on the end. The coin cell (CR1632, 3V) provides battery backup to keep the pyboard real time clock (RTC) going when the main battery pack or USB power are not connected.

See Look Think Make for construction details.

print_settings.Notes:: While these settings work great on my printer, my printer is a very "special" printer in that it doesn't always work perfectly, and various factors (How precise your printer is and whatnot) might need to change. Try it out and let me know what you find.

description.text:
I have always loved Rubik's cubes, but my collection is quite small, seeing as how I spent my hard earned money on an old 3D printer rather than more puzzles. After a lot of work and many hours of designing and printing and redesigning, I have my very first successful twisty puzzle.

One of the things I was looking for when I designed it was simplicity. Gluing things together, having a thousand pieces to print or needing other hardware is something that holds me back from printing many things on thingiverse, so I wanted to make a design that printed in a single piece and did not need any extra work or components to work. I am quite pleased with the design I came up with and I haven't seen anyone make one quite the same way.

It prints with the biggest side on the build plate so no pieces print on top of each other.

Edit: I have now included a version with a bigger gap in between pieces. This should be easier for lots of 3d printers, but will be a looser fitting puzzle so if you can get the original design to work than I would go with that. Enjoy!

Update 2: I Stickered my old puzzle and I Love it!

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

Thing-O-Matic

Resolution:

.3mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

While these settings work great on my printer, my printer is a very "special" printer in that it doesn't always work perfectly, and various factors (How precise your printer is and whatnot) might need to change. Try it out and let me know what you find.

It might be a bit stiff at first if some of the inside pieces fuse together a bit. Just pick it up and turn. Try all of the different ways and move pieces around. You need to add some coloring system to make it actually solvable. Stickers would work fine, but I just printed it yellow and used some sharpies. They soak into the plastic so it won't wear away very quickly, and if it does, I can always add some more.

Lots and lots of trial and error. I have printed at least 10 different renditions of this. Some of them worked better than the previous designs, and some of them failed miserably. I designed them in Solidworks so if anyone is interested in the files I would be happy to share.

title: Vertex K8400 Pulley and Belt Replacement

description.text:
After having troubles with Vertex K8400 printer's original T2.5/T19 pulleys (see my post http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1687458), I decided to replace them with more commonly used GT20 pulleys and GT2 belts.
To perform this modification you will need the following parts:

  • Two GT2 6mm wide belt rings with length 180mm (90 teeth)
  • About 3.5 meters of GT2 6mm timing belt
  • Ten GT20 pulleys with 8mm bore
  • Two GT20 pulleys with 5mm bore (for motors)
  • Four spring belt tensioners
  • One M4 or M5 countersunk (flat) screw and self-locking nut for it. The screw should be at least 12mm in length.

All the parts from the list above are available online. In addition you will need to print 4 copies of belt_holders thing and single copy of each motor mount.

I am posting the images that show the placement and orientation of the pulleys.

UPDATE 19-Feb-2017
My new post Print-head Mount Redesign contains improved belt clamps.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

VERTEX K8400

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

Print settings for motor_mounts:

  • Brim
  • 0.2mm
  • Support everywhere
  • Infill 50%

Print settings for belt holder:

  • Brim
  • 0.1mm
  • No Support
  • Infill 95%

Additional Notes

You will need to file down the upper part of AXIAL BEARING CLAMP mounted to the rear wall of the printer (above Y-axis motor) and replace it's upper screw with countersunk screw (see the image). This is required to clear the space for the rear left pulley. This is the only clamp that requires such modification.

New pulleys have slightly smaller diameter than the original ones that's why X and Y motors need to be attached via modified mounts, which place them lower than the original position. My belt tensioner (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1853756) will help you to tighten the motor belts.

When mounting long belts, replace original belt clamps with the clamps posted here. The belt ends should be placed between 2 clamp pieces with teeth facing the bigger piece.

This carriage alignment things http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:606083 are very handy when doing final adjustments.

Firmware update
You will need to modify one line in configuration.h file and then update printer firmware.
See the define command on the image below.

If you installed my wire covers http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1504532 you will probably need to file down x_motor_extr1 piece or replace it with x_motor_extr1_rev2.

Does it worth the effort?
I think it definitely does. The quality of the prints is much better. If the old minimal linear step length was 0.00742mm, the new value is 0.00625mm (about 16% improvement). GT2 belts with round teeth are considered the better fit for 3d printing applications comparing to T2.5 belts with rectangular teeth. And finally the maintenance cost down the road will be much lower since the original parts are more expensive and harder to find.

comments.text: Hi, did you use PLA or ABS for the motor mounts?
comments.author: pinthenet99

comments.text: I don't have heated bed required for ABS printing, so everything I've ever printed is in PLA. It should not snap. I'd check if print-bed is leveled, if the distance between the bed and nozzle is correct, if temperature is correct for the filament you are using. There could be lots of other reasons as you probably know. My 1st layer thickness is set to 0.8mm, shell thickness 0.7mm (have to be 2 times nozzle diameter), 1st layer speed 15. I printed mounts with 50% infill and using them since publishing this thing without a problem.

description.text: This is a peg that you can 3D print and use for DBA. DBA is a game played with armies of ancient solders. These blocks and pegs can replace the painted miniatures. It is to mounted into a painted block of wood. Then wet-Erase markers (or even Sharpie) can be used to write what the abbreviation for kind of unit the block represents. The blocks should be the size of the bases that would hold figures. Great if you enjoy using a wide variety of army, but don't have hours to spend painting or money to buy figures.

Printer Brand:

Deezmaker

Printer:

Bukobot V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3 mm

Infill:

15%

Notes:

you may need to tweak settings on your printer to get the peg to fit into the hole. The hole is 1/8 of an inch. Make sure the bed is level to get a smooth surface on the bottom of the print. This is required to write onto the surface with a marker. I also recommend printing multiple at a time in order to get better posts on the pegs.

Sanding

The shaft of the piece might need a small amount filing or sanding to get them to fit. The surface that was on the bed must be smooth.

Blocks

The blocks the pegs were put into were cut from 3/4 in plywood. 1/8 in holes were drilled in the middle. The blocks were then pained and finshed.

title: Remix-MP Select Mini Controller Board 50mm Fan Mount!

description.text:
This is a remix of https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1667026 however it is modified to accept a 50mm fan rather a 40mm as we all know bigger is of course better! There are two versions the fist is like the original requires M3 stand offs (you can find them here: http://amzn.to/2eko3FG) whereas version 2 has the standoffs designed in. Also you can get the 50mm fans (here: http://amzn.to/2e6gm8N) if your looking for them. Also the fan is 12VDC and simply soldered into the back of the board where the power leads connect just be sure to get the polarity correct and I have added two pictures to you understand the placement.

To learn more about this and our other prints, please visit http://www.DIY3DTech.com as well check out our YouTube Channel at http://YouTube.DIy3DTech.com to learn more about 3D Printing, CNC Machining, and CO2 Laser cutting & engraving! Also if you are looking for maker swag be sure to check out http://Swag.DIY3Dtech.com for one of a kind Maker Swag!

Printer:

Monoprice Select Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3 or better

Infill:

50

Notes:

Easy to print and install, as you can either use the offsets (find them here: http://amzn.to/2dVg2q0) or 20mm M3's (find them here: http://amzn.to/2ekiBTx). The fan is a stand 50mm (find them here: http://amzn.to/2e6gm8N). In short, it is a simple and quick build which add life to your Monoprice Select Mini by keeping it cooling those long prints!

title: Simple Receiver Box for traxxas or ECX or Other RC vehicles

description.text:
I designed this simple receiver box for my traxxas rustler because
I wanted something simple so to make things easier to install
the receiver and wiring without the complicated design of the traxxas
receiver box that usually comes with the rustler. But this simple receiver box
can also be use in the ECX circuit or other RC vehicle that will accept this
simple receiver box. If you wish to download this file you will need two
screws they need to be about 3 x 15mm and you will need double-sided tape and some superglue two glue on the logo plate on top of the receiver box. and what you will see in the photos will give you an idea how to install it. You may need to do some sanding
to smooth out all of the rough edges to make it easier to put on or removed the lid off
of the receiver box. What you will see in this photos I have to fix the design a bit
so you will not have to drill bigger holes where the screws will go into the lid part of the
Simple Receiver Box. and what you see in the photos is my youtube logo design on the
logo plate, but what you will download the logo plate is blank to allow you to put your
own logo on it. So enjoy this part.

description.text:
UPDATE: re-uploaded the file per phillthomas's request.

loosely based on magpul's new ranger plate, the g36 speed plate allows for faster draw and better manipulation of a g36 magazine.

plate fits both standard 50rd and 400rd magazines with cut out for the tensioning wheel and space allow you to actually put your finger onto the wheel (unlike some m4 magazine plates).

installation is minimal, loose one screw, remove the old one, pop the plate in, screw it in and that is.

description.text:
easy printable;
not tested yet ;-)
An exploration of joint probability distributions by experimentation.

Print a couple sets of the coins, as well as the set of cups. Put the coins into the correspondingly shaped cup and shake so they are mixed up.   
What is the probability of getting a coin with A vs a coin with B?  Empirically study by first rolling the die to determine the cup to sample from, and then sample without looking.   Use the coin to track the experiment.

description.text: This is an Imperial Guard baton/sword thing that I made to accompany this amazing mask http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:349643. It's slightly embellished from the actual batons in the movie, but you never get a really good look at the movie version anyway. The multiple pieces are printed out in an order that I felt was easier to print, and easier to finish.

Printer:

Prusa i3 XL

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.15

Infill:

5%

Notes:

The included .SCAD file declares a FACES variable at the top that manipulates the number of polygons used throughout.

I used a 1/2" PVC pipe (1/2" is the reported inner diameter) for the actual shaft, you can grab one at most home supply stores. A 10' section of pipe costs less than $5, so this seemed smarter than printing all of it. I cut the pipe to 1 meter, putting the total length at approximately 122cm with the top and the bottom added.

The pieces are all ordered from top to bottom in the order they fit together, top being the pointy end. I glued some of them together before fitting to the pipe, but this isn't necessary. Each part was spray painted before sliding it over the painted PVC pipe and gluing in to place with cyanoacrylate (superglue). You should deburr the insides of pieces 2-3-4 in order to avoid scraping the paint off the pipe. The rest of the pieces will cover and scratched paint.

The bottom two pieces (9 and 10) might need something in between them to make them sit flush, I used a bit of JB Weld to fill the gap.

description.text:
Polygon Based Calculator  
This calculator can be used add, subtract, multiply and divide small numbers. The calculator works by rotating 11 sided polygons to display digits [0-9 and a blank space].

Step One: Print the file: Poloh-Calculator-Case.stl with the medium resolution setting.
Step Two: Print the file: Polygons and Bars.stl with the high resolution setting.
Step Three: Make sure the polygons are smooth to ensure that they don't get stuck when rotating by removing any residue.
Step Five: Use a black [or any other colour you like] marking pen to write down the digits on 25 polygons [numbers 0-9 and leave an empty space]. Use another colour to mark 9 polygons, 5 of these should have the numbers 0-9 and an empty space and the reaming 4 should have the addition, subtract, multiply, divide and equals symbols on them.
Step Six: Slide 6 polygons into each of the 6 bars and close the case.
Step Seven: Use the penÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂ to rotate the polygons [if your finger tips are too big]. I found that an object with a metal tip [like a precision screwdriver] works very well in rotating the polygons, IMPORTANT: Make sure the holes in the polygons are as perfectly circular as possible, this will ensure that the polygons stay in the desired position and don'ÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂt get displased from their position. This also applies to the bars where the polygons will be slid onto. Optional: The calculator's size can be increased by adjusting the scale of the .stl files. One side of the polygon is 2.4mm x 5mm, increasing the scale will increase the surface area. This will allow for larger and clearer numbers.

title: 08 Dodge Caravan HVAC blender door actuator gear

description.text: This is a common failure for Dodge vehicles. Mine made a clicking noise when changing from hot to cold and got stuck on hot only, then continued making a clicking noise for ~10 minutes, sometimes even with the engine off and key removed. Not fun on a 3 hour road trip. This was on the drivers side. Grease the gear before reinstalling. Remember to calibrate the actuator when reinstalling or it may strip again. Should also work for other models with the same actuator, Dodge Ram, Avenger, Caravan, Town & Country, etc.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

95

Notes:

2 shells, printed in ABS for durability. ReplicatorG said there was a hole in the mesh but it printed just fine.

Clean up

After printing use a drill to clear the center bore, bit size 11/64". use a small triangle file to clean up the teeth a little if necessary. I only had to run the file through the larger diameter gear teeth very lightly to square them up.

This is a small, quick printing, flying toy. Spinning the Air Top like normal top (except handle facing down) should be enough to provide some positive vertical motion. To get higher/longer flights the Air Top can be spun using by placing the handle between your middle finger and thumb while snapping your fingers.

This toy can be modified using the "Open in Customizer" button in Thingiverse. Or you can download the .scad file and open the design with OpenSCAD on your computer and modify it there.

The three bladed version shown uses the default settings in customizer. The two bladed version shown requires a 40mm handle and changing the number of blades from three to two.

These models print in about 6 minutes, I used:
Layer Height: 0.2 mm
Wall Thickness of 0.8 mm
and 25% fill for the prints shown in the pictures/video.

Here is a very short YouTube video showing them in action: https://youtu.be/o-odv3DL_RA

author: Loganator100

description.text: After seeing 4MULE8's wonderful sea turtle I knew I had to do something with ball joints. This snake is comprised of an arbitrary number of body segments, plus tail tip and head. Each segment is fitted with one or two ball joints that mate flush and allow limited movement. Currently only the body segment is available.

As there is not a lot of contact between the model base and the build plate I recommend printing PLA directly onto an acrylic build plate. Prints just fine with standard settings (2 shells, 10% infill, 0.20mm layer height) in a little over an hour.  
Internal support structures are used to help ensure successful printing. These break away and are only evidenced by an initial slight grinding. In fact, the supports are so fragile that simply removing the model from the build plate breaks the lower joint free and the upper will break away with very little effort, if any.  
When planning for size note that the body length is about two inches per segment (they are slightly over 40mm, but the ball joints extend out enough to add the missing centimeter). The tail tip and head will be of similar length.  
Due to limitations of the interlock dimensions to get the body segment to this size required having the prongs go entirely through the ball socket. To allow this to work there is a cavity behind the lower ball socket to allow the prongs through. So to join two segments ensure the lower ball is oriented as it is when printed (the whole is completely vertical), squeeze the prongs together and push firmly. It will be fully engaged when the balls are flush.  
The sizing of the cavity behind the lower ball joint is a bit close so the prongs may contact the interior enough to grind a little at extremes.

title: Mini Talon Collapsible Launch Hook
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I wanted a collapsible launch hook for the Mini Talon because there are days without wind where I would rather use my bungee than risk a hand launch. This piece then glues on/into the fuse right up against the front wheel hump. It is additionally secured by two prongs of plastic which are buried in the hump foam.

As in my other Collapsible Bungee Tow Hook, it uses an aluminum tube for the hook part with a 3mm pivot bolt. For glue I use either white tube glue or Beacons FoamTac.

-Assembly-
Only four simple parts. The hook piece is made from 5/16" (8mm) aluminum tubing 35mm long with a cross drill 3mm hole at 5/16" from one end. The bolt is a 20mm M3 screw cut down to fit and the nut is an M3 Nyloc hex nut.

-Configurations-
After releasing this idea I got some feedback from an RCG poster who requested I tweak the angle a little so that the bungee ring won't slip off. I made this change adding ~10 degrees to the angle and additionally created a printable "tip" which should help even more with ring slippage.

For more information, please see my build Wiki here:
http://www.itsqv.com/QVM/index.php?title=Mini_Talon_Collapsible_Launch_Hook

More Mini Talon Parts!
http://www.itsqv.com/QVM/index.php?title=Mini_Talon_Parts_Compilation

After using Vertex K8400 printer for about 6 months I discovered that rods started to move lengthwise due to worn out plastic end-caps. Several solutions addressing this have been posted here, but I decided to come up with my own that uses steel balls from old 608 bearings. The balls allow to minimize the area of contact with the rod, which reduces friction.

You will need 8 balls in total. One bearing contains 7 balls, so you will need to disassemble 2 bearings.

You will also need four M3x16mm cup-headed bolts and four M3 self-locking nuts.

Print 4 copies of rod_holder.stl. I printed small cylinder with 0.1mm resolution and bigger thing with 0.2mm. No support or brim is required. Infill 20%

Remove 4 end-cups - 2 from the front and 2 from the right side of the printer. Drill a recess in the very center of the end-cups with 3.5mm drill-bit. The depth should be between 1/3 and 1/2 of the ball diameter. Then glue the balls to the centers of end-cups as shown on the images.

Remove the remaining 4 end-cups. We will replace them with rod_holder things.

Place the M3 nut inside the bigger thing and fix it in this position with M3 bolt. Slide in the small cylinder into the bigger thing with cut edge facing the nut. Place the ball inside the small cylinder and mount this assembly to the printer. Make sure the ball does not fall out.

Once the glue dries mount the end-cups to the other ends of the rods. Tighten all end-cup mounting bolts. Finally tighten M3 cup-headed bolts just enough to stop rods' lengthwise movement.

title: Y Axis Rod holder - remixed for 20x20 alu profiles

description.text:
I remixed this thing to fit for my 20x20 alu profiles with m5 nuts.
Depending on your printer and your print settings, you might want to loosen the holes where the screws go through a bit or make a thread.

If you happen to use half sized m5 nuts in your profile instead of the nuts that are usually used for these profiles (which are quite expensive related to m5 nuts), then you might want to use an 16mm long m5 screw with a full sized m5 nut screwed to the end of the screw to have the perfect screw size. 12mm screws seem to be to short (at least for me).

author: photonix

description.text:
continuing my development on Youmagine. https://www.youmagine.com/designs/napier-s-bones The reason i am stopping development is Makerbot (the owner of thingiverse) has begun applying for patents for works done by the opensource printing community. This is theft of intellectual properties. I will leave this file up, but all future developments will be done elsewhere. http://www.openbeamusa.com/blog/2014/5/22/stay-classy-makerbot Napier's bones are a mechanical calculator that helps students relate multiplication of single digit numbers to simple addition and multiplication table.
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Napier's_bones

comments.text: We are all stealing from each other here... we call it sharing or in modern words: open source
comments.author: criopt

comments.text: Using an open source project is not steeling. Applying for patents on open source works is, not only is it unethical, but if proven intentional it is a crime punishable by prison time. Makerbot filed patents on works developed by the users of thingiverse and stated that they were planning on using these patents to gain competitive advantage.
comments.author: criopt

comments.text: I don't know how it works where you are, but you are only right if the Makerbot terms and conditions state that users of this site forfeit the rights to uploaded content.
comments.author: Fennecbutt

comments.text: The reason I moved my stuff is because it already happened. I am working on a filament identification project with some others. and months after we started Makerbot filled a patent that is almost verbatim the work i had done (subset of my work). After that i had to spend hours collecting documentation that proves my work was public and came before as prior art. In the end the patent will be invalidated (may already be) but it is the attitude that they can steal from the community is wrong.
comments.author: Fennecbutt

comments.text: If they are stupid enough to patent something that has an obvious prior art in the open source community....

description.text:
I scrapped a mini laptop and got away with a 8.9 lcd. Ordered up one of those lcd controller pcbs and made a nice enclosure for it.

You will need a LCD model HSD089IFW1-A00 and a M.NT68676.2 controller for it.
The controller needs to be ordered for this specific lcd or you wont get the correct lvds cable and firmware on it.

This is the one i ordered.
http://www.ebay.com/itm/272211605195?_trksid=p2060353.m2749.l2649&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT

You will also need some screws:
4x M2 4mm screws for the LCD
2x M3 10mm screws for mounting the pcb holder to the enclosure
4x M4 10mm screws to mount the pcb on the pcb holder
4x M3 6mm screws to secure the backplate to the lcd assembly

Edit 04.11.2016
Print is tested and fits correctly. Backplate has a mount for buttons now.

Also be ware when using with foods: the pores will incubate bacteria and the like.

title: Small Fume Hood for Soldering or even a 3D Printer

description.text:
Ever get tired of the usual bulky fume hoods getting in the way when you are soldering a circuit board? Yep, that's what inspired this design. ...and, had an extra 40mm fan laying around... It looks kind odd. I'll have to admit. But, that oddity is exactly what makes it versitile. It works fine. I am still waiting on a charcol filter that I can insert into the slot just in front of the fan. As a note, the 2 little open mesh filter supports will go on either side of this filter and then inserted into the slot. Thought I might put some extra filter material into the hollow body once it arrives. What else? Oh, it doesn't slice exactly right for me. Had to sand the surface where the fan mounts. You can see the artifacts in the one image. Also, the fan mounting holes are a bit off, but everytime I tried to make changes, the slicing render got worse. :-( Sadly, guess I need to find a better design tool than Sketchup. It is fine for simple designs, but add in a couple of stacked elements and it starts to export to STL terribly. IMHO. Anyways... Hope it is useful to someone. Have a great day.
Bill.

comments.text: For a good CAD tool, try OnShape. It should fit the bill... Use several CAD package, but this kind of work, it's just excellent (and free). Worth to mention, never had any issue with an exported STL.

title: Beaker bottom with extended treeee perc
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Good day, today i bring a beaker bottom with a extended quad tree perc, the dimensions are 181mmx139mmx176mm. The design is 3d printable and I reccomend Slic3r/Cura/simplify 3d for the gcode because some other programs skip layers. Good Luck.

For more info take a look at the .docx files and for more info on how to print successfully and health safety.

NEVER LIGHT PLASTIC ON FIRE, THE POISONOUS FUMES ARE DEADLY, use a glass bowl or attachment. I do not condone under age smoking,

Printer:

Tevo Tarantula

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

200-300 microns (.2mm-.3mm)

Infill:

100% rectilinear (is a must)

Notes:

Before printing the beaker bottom I highly suggest checking your printer calibration with 18mm.stl and comparing it with comparison.jpg. 100% rectilinear infill is a must and requires about 250gms of filament. Print slow for best results possible and make sure to have adhesion (glue/painters tape/ hair spray) to avoid any warping due to it's large print size. Good day and good Luck

NEVER LIGHT PLASTIC ON FIRE, THE POISONOUS FUMES ARE DEADLY, use a glass bowl or attachment. I do not condone under age smoking,

WORK IN PROGRESS -- design commentary is occurring in the #RepRap IRC channel on FreeNode and in this forum thread.

This is an inverted cantilever delta 3D printer, in the same evolutionary tree as the RepRap GUS Simpson and Solidus Labs' Dogleg GDR. I thought I saw a unique way to solve the motion platform problems by adding a parallel linkage and moving the motor to the bottom link, where it's driven by a fixed gear/pulley system instead of a winch+spring or motor-at-the-top like the current approaches.

title: Extra Missiles for Imaginext Toys PEW PEW PEW

description.text: The Fisher-Price Imaginext line of toys is pretty cool, but they never give you enough missiles to shoot all the bad guys. But if you print out four of these for your Imaginext Windscorpion and you'll have one missile for the tail launcher, one for each wing, and one for the dog to eat.

Print the body with support and a brim.  The head should be printed without support and can probably be printed without a brim or anything.  Use ~30% infill for both.  
After printing both parts, do some clean up on the body and attach it permanently to the head with a drop of cyanoacrylate (Krazy Glue).  
The Sketchup source file is provided and it is scaled 10x size to workaround precision issues.

In today's mobile world it isn't uncommon for PC keyboards to be moved between locations. And without being fixed to a desk they can slide away from the users preferred location, or even fall off the desk! Furthermore, whilst the keyboard is out in the open it can be a target for passing theives, so you might not want to permanently fix the keyboard to the desk, so that you take it with you.

With these corner pieces you can restrain keyboard movement whilst retaining the ability to take the keyboard with you.

You can fix these corner places to a desk using double-sided tape, so these can be removed without leaving unsightly holes behind.

title: Eachine-EF-01 camera mount for 90mm carbon frame

description.text:
Camera mound designed for Eachine-EF-01 FPV camera and carbon copter frame found on banggood:

http://www.banggood.com/90mm-Carbon-Fiber-DIY-Micro-Mini-FPV-Quadcopter-Frame-Kit-2mm-Support-8_5x20mm-Coreless-Motor-p-1055212.html

http://www.banggood.com/Eachine-EF-01-AIO-5_8G-40CH-25MW-VTX-800TVL-13-Cmos-FPV-Camera-p-1064301.html

Material: PETg/PLA
Layer: 0.15 (0.2 also good)
Infill: 40% (or more)
Support: Everywhere
Platform adhesion: Brim

I have also designed propquards for frame mentioned above:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1778545
